data.title: Esports World Cup kicks off in Saudi Arabia, but not without controversy
data.meta_description: The esports World Cup has begun in Saudi Arabia, but critics say the event is an attempt at sportswashing.
data.text:
Critics say Saudi Arabia is ‘sportwashing’ with event

⭐️HERE’S WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW⭐️

The Esports World Cup kicked off in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on July 3.

The event runs until Aug. 25 and includes 1,500 esports players from around the world.

Fortnite, League of Legends and Call of Duty are among the featured games.

But some people are criticizing the event.

Keep on reading to find out why. ⬇️ ⬇️ ⬇️

Gamers far and wide are moving their attention from their consoles to one of the biggest esports events ever.

On July 2, the first ever Esports World Cup (EWC) began at Boulevard City in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, bringing together thousands of the world’s biggest and best esports players.

The festival, which lasts until Aug. 25, includes more than $60 million US (about $81 million Cdn) in prizes, one of the largest prize pools in esports history.

“The Esports World Cup is a major moment in esports history,” said Ralf Reichert, CEO of the Esports World Cup Foundation in a news release.

Organizers say the world cup is the next big step in the esports global phenomenon, but some critics say the event is Saudi Arabia’s latest attempt at “sportswashing.”

Sportswashing is when countries use sporting events to try and “clean up” their image on the world stage.

3 things to know about Faker, League of Legends world champion

Games on deck

The EWC opening ceremony included streamers like Faker, Tyler1 (loltyler1) and Danny Aarons.

More than 1,500 esports players from the top esports clubs around the world are participating, according to organizers.

The eight-week tournament will include 22 competitions in 21 games, including:

Apex Legends.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III.

Call of Duty: Warzone.

Counter-Strike 2.

Dota 2.

EA Sports FC 24.

Fortnite.

Free Fire.

Honor of Kings.

League of Legends.

Mobile Legends: Bang Bang.

Overwatch 2.

PUBG Battlegrounds.

PUBG Mobile.

ESL R1.

Rocket League.

StarCraft II.

Street Fighter 6.

Teamfight Tactics.

Tekken 8.

Tom Clancy’s Rainbow 6 Siege.

Of the total prize pool, $20 million US (about $27 million Cdn) is reserved for a unique award called the Club Championship.

POLL — Olympic Esports Series began last week. Which game would you play?

The championship is awarded to the gaming club with the most overall championships across all games in the tournament.

But it’s not all about gaming — the EWC has transformed Riyadh into an “epicentre of esports fandom” with a host of events and celebrations throughout the eight weeks.

Event criticized for sportswashing

Not everyone is celebrating this event.

In April, esports YouTuber Travis Gafford — who has 213,000 subscribers — published a video saying that he would not be watching or covering the tournament.

“I’m incredibly uncomfortable with esports deciding to partner with a government who has a terrible track record of human rights abuses,” he said.

Indeed, according to Amnesty International, Saudi Arabia has a history of discrimination against women, limiting freedom of speech and detaining political opponents, among other human rights violations.

Gafford said he’s heard many people suggest that, in order to survive, the gaming industry can’t afford to pass on opportunities like the one in Saudi Arabia.

Gaming expert Geoffrey Lachapelle, who manages the Red Bull Gaming Hub at Toronto Metropolitan University (TMU), said teams are in a difficult position when considering whether to participate, but it often comes down to money.

“[Teams] need to continue to operate as a business,” he said.

“There are very few options for them to compete at a world stage level. And this is one of the biggest in terms of prize pool.”

On June 10, Victor Goossens, CEO of Team Liquid, one of the biggest esports teams, said in a video on X that deciding to participate in the event was not an easy one.

Goossens called out Saudi Arabia’s track record on human rights, and said any team members who didn’t feel comfortable attending had the organization’s support.

“We believe that if Team Liquid does not participate in the largest and most influential events in our space, especially one that lasts a duration of two months, that over time we cannot be a top tier organization within esports.”

Esports school is a dream come true for Montreal teen

According to Reuters, Saudi Arabia has denied accusations of human rights abuses and says it protects its national security through its laws.

In September 2023, Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman addressed the accusations of sportwashing and didn’t deny them.

In an interview with Fox News, he said he doesn’t care about sportswashing and will continue to fund sports if it makes the country richer.

Results already coming in

And for the fans, this fun has already started.

Among some of the notable results, Team Liquid beat Fnatic in League of Legends, “a big win in the classic North America-Europe rivalry in that game,” according to Lachapelle.

“This is something that really connects with people internationally and across every major region of the world and brings a lot of fans together to watch this kind of content,” he said.
